security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill with pattern examples. Contains instructional code snippets for IaC tools but no executable scripts, no file writes, and no network calls. Risk factors are standard devops capabilities used in illustrative examples.

content.value_statement: Developers need reliable patterns for deploying infrastructure across multiple cloud providers. This skill provides ready-to-use implementations for Terraform, Pulumi, GitOps workflows, and progressive delivery strategies.
actual_capabilities: Generate Terraform and Pulumi configurations for multi-cloud deployments
Build GitOps pipelines with ArgoCD and Flux for continuous deployment
Implement canary and blue-green deployment strategies
Manage infrastructure state across AWS, Azure, and GCP
Configure progressive delivery with traffic splitting and metrics analysis
Create failover strategies for disaster recovery
limitations: Does not execute infrastructure changes automatically
Requires existing cloud credentials and kubectl configuration
Does not provision cloud resources directly
Does not include monitoring or alerting setup

use_cases.title: Standardize deployment patterns
use_cases.description: Create consistent infrastructure patterns across multiple teams and cloud providers using Terraform and GitOps.

use_cases.title: Build internal developer platforms
use_cases.description: Implement self-service infrastructure provisioning with safe progressive delivery and automated rollback capabilities.

use_cases.title: Improve deployment reliability
use_cases.description: Deploy with confidence using canary analysis, health checks, and automated failover for production services.

prompt_templates.title: Create Terraform config
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Terraform backend configuration for deploying a web application to AWS with an S3 bucket, RDS database, and EC2 instances in us-east-1.

prompt_templates.title: Set up GitOps pipeline
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up an ArgoCD application that syncs from a GitHub repository to deploy a Kubernetes application with automatic sync enabled.

prompt_templates.title: Implement canary deployment
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure a canary deployment for my API service that starts with 10% traffic and automatically promotes or rolls back based on error rate metrics.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-cloud failover
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a multi-cloud deployment strategy that deploys the same application to AWS and GCP with automatic DNS failover if the primary region becomes unhealthy.

output_examples.input: Create a Terraform configuration for a highly available web application on AWS
output: ✓ Terraform backend configured with S3 state storage
✓ VPC with public and private subnets across 3 availability zones
✓ Application Load Balancer with health checks
✓ Auto Scaling Group with rolling update policy
✓ Security groups restricting inbound traffic to port 443
✓ Outputs for load balancer DNS name and instance IDs

best_practices: Always run terraform plan before apply to review changes
Use remote state backends with encryption for production
Implement health checks before increasing traffic in canary deployments
Enable drift detection to catch configuration changes outside GitOps
anti_patterns: Do not hardcode credentials in Terraform variable files
Avoid manual kubectl edits that break GitOps synchronization
Do not skip validation steps before production deployments
Avoid deploying to production without a rollback strategy

faq.question: Which IaC tools are supported?
faq.answer: This skill provides patterns for Terraform, Pulumi, and AWS CDK. Each has backend implementations for initialization, planning, applying, and destruction.

faq.question: What deployment strategies are available?
faq.answer: Rolling updates, blue-green deployments, and canary releases with configurable traffic splitting and automatic promotion or rollback.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my cloud resources?
faq.answer: No. This skill generates configuration patterns and code examples. You must execute terraform apply, kubectl, or pulumi up yourself.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a read-only documentation skill. It does not access your files, credentials, or cloud accounts directly.

faq.question: How do I connect to my Kubernetes cluster?
faq.answer: Configure kubectl with your cluster credentials. The skill reads KUBECONFIG environment variable to run commands against your cluster.

faq.question: How does this compare to manual deployments?
faq.answer: This skill provides tested patterns that reduce human error, enable repeatable deployments, and add safety through automated rollback and validation.
